title: Learning Design for Post-Secondary Courses using SDGs
segmentation: So hi everyone, my name is Jenny Haven and I will tell you a bit about myself, but I want to start with is gratitude, which I think is a really great kind of part of the open movement to Tonya and to Mitya into Anya for all of their work in helping this to happen.

They are the people that I've had the most close contact with, in addition to my mentors, I think it's a wonderful program and even though I'm a fairly mature instructional designer and open education movement.
Community participants I always have something to learn and definitely learned many things from my mentors in this project and working in the area.
That's fairly new to me.
The Sustainable Development Goals as they relate to design.
So I am doctoral candidate, so I am at Arizona State University working on my Ed D Doctor of Education in Leadership and Innovation.
I'm also a member of the Global O ER graduate network Go GN, which is a really great privilege to do my doctoral work with that group for my professional work.
So I'm working full time and doing an Ed D, so I'm living in talking and we are kind of all day and all night.

I work for Ecampus Ontario, which is a government funded organization in Ontario, Canada and our mandate is to support 24 community colleges, 21 universities in Ontario with support for technology enabled, teaching and learning.
And my particular job that I love is building open community and raising awareness and use of O ER in Ontario.
That's also my doctoral research.
So as I say, all day all night we are.

But I became quite interested in the Sustainable Development Goals related to design work because of inquiry based learning, which is something that I studied and practiced pedagogically as part of distance education with several science educators.
So that's a bit about me.
Just make sure I haven't forgotten anything.
I think I have email and I have Twitter.
I'm a huge Twitter user.
I find my global community in Twitter and so I'm connected with lots of people like Martin Weller and Bayo de Los Arcos and 1100 others.
my Twitter account.
So in terms of mentors for this project, I had two mentors, Doctor Rory Mcgreal from Athabasca University in Canada.
He is also the UNESCO Commonwealth of Learning Chair for O ER in Canada and quite a character so many of you may know Rory.
He was one of my mentors and his focus for me in this project was to not create original material but ensure that I'm using oers kind of walking.
That walk of practice.
My practice is very applied.
As I say, I'm an instructional designer and so although I have studied pedagogic theory and do understand it very well.
And distance education theory.
I work in the kind of the trenches of design.
My other mentor was Doctor Pedro Mendoza.
Arana from Lima, Peru, and he's a physician, Ana Public health director of public health at his University of San Marcos, and he was a really interesting mentor to have in terms of creating examples.
I'm still working on his example for public health, so I can share it with you today.
This work that I'm doing is a work in progress.

In progress because there are so many sustainable development goals and so many possibilities for the types of examples that I could show with inquiry based learning, I'm still building some of the examples out.
So the project itself for me is.

Is designing modules and there are five modules in my series that will help in educator who is not familiar with the SDGS not familiar with Ovr at all or very introductory to begin to learn more about SDGS more about Ovr and more about inquiry based learning.
So it's a series of modules that tide those three things together at an introductory level.
And then how you might begin in multiple disciplines to use that for your course.
The basis of your course or for assessments in your course.
So as many opportunities as possible I was took part in a workshop recently with a woman named Julia Forsythe, who is a visual notetaker.
She's fantastic.
You've probably seen some of her work.
But I walk through what does this project look like inside my head and it looks like this.
It's iterative, it has peaks and valleys and as things go up, things go down an I typically come back around to the start again.
So my work as I say very applied mixed methods, very iterative.
So that's kind of what it looks like in my head.
And again, I'm combining these things Stainable development goals, O ER, Creative Commons license inquiry based learning.
Because what I believe about those things is that they empower learners.
My philosophy, my teaching philosophy, my design philosophy is extremely learner centers.
I really enjoyed Peters talked this morning about.
About the Inter Inter.
Cultural, intergenerational, open NIS and learners have such capacity no matter their age.
To connect and to teach each other.
Facilitating is important, but I think there's so much about the SDGS O ER in IBL that can be very learner centric and also interdisciplinary.
So when I talk about the SDGS, I'm talking about all 16.
Plus, you know, finding a way to make them all work together collaboratively?
Any one of them, any discipline?
How can we find a way to get learners to pick and choose to learn the SDGS and decide for themselves what they'd like to learn?
So again, this is the purpose of the combination of these things.
Learner engagement and learner choice.
If I give this learners the entire list of SDGS, all the targets and all the indicators, and I ask them if they can find something local and contextual to them about this list.
It's pretty much a guarantee that they can.
Pick anyone, no poverty, no one lives in a place in the world where there's no poverty or where it's not an issue.
In Canada, we're talking right now about truth and reconciliation with our indigenous peoples or First Nations.
There's so much about the sustainable development Goals that's completely relatable to the conversations we're having about truth and reconciliation.
So again, localized contextual, culturally specific, so as a teaching strategy you can ask learners to take the.
Very big, complex problems of the world and localising contextualize for themselves.
Or for their communities or for their families.
Inclusive, inflexible design and again I'm a very big proponent of Accessibility and design.
Inclusion in design, Universal design for learning.
The continuous improvement assessment model I've heard this called throw away assignments.
I'm not a big fan of that.
I don't like that language very much.
Sustainable, renewable, continuous improvement.

If I can have one class of learners were kind of project or work on multiple projects that are interesting to them and I can retain what they were they have worked on and move it to the next class of learners, then we're building on things and we're not doing projects that are only useful in one class or for one student.
Connecting global learners and educators with each other.
So again, with the Sustainable Development Goals, these are worldwide problems in every community.

Everyone can talk about these problems if you connect learners with each other and they talk about, here's what's happening in my place and someone across the ocean is saying here's what's happening in my place.
Then they're learning from each other, right?
And then this is contributing to global success.
We only have 12 years to go until 2030.
If we want to scale up.
Quickly how we are looking at the Sustainable Development Goals in the millions of postsecondary students in the world.
If we connect them with one another, we have a way of scaling up.
And so why inquiry based learning inquiry based learning has been predominantly in the Sciences very much in K12 contexts.
It's coming around to postsecondary.
And really what it what it entails is citizen research, Community research, learner research.
So it's an academic process that can be taught in terms of discernment, of materials in terms of curation of materials.
Digital literacy's if you're doing it in a digital way so it has a lot to offer.
Inquiry based learning and it's about curiosity.
Right, I want my learners to be very curious.
I want them to ask questions.
I want them to think critically and inquiry based learning gives me opportunities to do that.
So if you haven't heard of inquiry based learning very much in your practice or your discipline, there are a few definitions of it.
I won't read them out, but what I find are the common elements of these three definitions are taking a look at real world problems SDGS perfect fit.
Um students driven so not just student centered or learner centered, but learner driven learning where the learner chooses the topic that they're going to research.
It's supported, right?
It's facilitated by a faculty member, but Learner choice is really important.
Investigations questioning all those kinds of things that I think are so good for the mind.
And seeking new knowledge is also one that stands out in these definitions for me, and so it's not globe new global knowledge, necessarily.
It's knowledge that's just new for the learner that they can share with their peers, and this can also be done collaboratively.
Right, so you're getting all the pedagogic.
The good pedagogic mix when you talk about SDGS and Ibla.
So one of the pieces of literature that I like to look at is Podesta ET al.
Won't read them all out 'cause I'll get half of them wrong.
So Podesta and colleagues did a systematic literature review of postsecondary IBL who was using it.
How are they using it?
What kind of tasks were they asking learners to do?
And they came up with a framework that's somewhat similar to something called the Five ES.
So the five Isar engage, explore three other ease.

About inquiry based learning, this is slightly different model and I like this model for a variety of reasons because the the reflection there's this does the discussion that goes on among peers or between a learner and their instructor is iterative.
We're talking about this reflecting it all the time.
And this process generates multiple types of learning strategies.
Multiple types of assessments they have that are possible as you kind of go through the process.
The purpose of inquiry based learning is one of its purposes is to accidentally teach the foundational knowledge you want learners to find.
So if you're teaching a chemistry course and you give them the SDGS, and you tell them to pick one, they still have to get the foundational knowledge of chemistry in order to answer the question.
In order to do their exploration.
So it's a little bit of incidental and accidental learning, but it ends up being part of the mix.
So why the SDGS?
Again, in my world, although I'm sure the United Nations and UNESCO thought really carefully about these indicators and targets.
They're really flexible.
A learner can look at this.
And look at the target prevent and significantly reduce marine pollution of all kinds.
If I live anywhere near water in the world, I can take a look at that and think what is my local context for that is my local River polluted is my local pond polluted?
Is there evidence that that Fish and Wildlife aren't doing well in my system?
So there's lots of opportunities within that target, and although the indicator here is quite complex and has a global measurement feel to it, a learner can decide on their own measurement.
I'm going to take the pH level in my local pond and see if acid rain is having an effect.
So I think there are a lot of different ways.
To take a look at that and the example that I've used in my modules that I will show you is of a high school, a young high school student, fictitious.
Her name is Naomi.
She's a First Nation student and she's checking the effect of pH on wildlife on her First Nations Reserve.
While we are, I think the conference like this we are is a pretty obvious and good choice for a variety of reasons.
But I think for the most part for me, oh, the reason that I practice all we are is so that I can teach it to my students.

I want them to learn how to use the Internet for their own knowledge, the knowledge of their peers, and the knowledge of others as a public good, I want them to learn how to do that, and the only way I can do that is if I model it and give them the opportunities to use and adapt to the materials that they find for their course and share with others.
And again, this idea of learner portfolios, the research that they do is it's their research right?
They can demonstrate by having a portfolio.
Here's what I did.
Here's the work that I did that matters to my community that matters to me personally.
And they can share it, and that longitudinal work.
It can be built on by the next cohort.
If it's an O ER, then the teacher knows that I have given you my permission as a learner.
You can use it with the next class if you want to.
And again helping to establish knowledge as a public good, especially around the sustainable development Goals.
The more that we can build and share the knowledge that we're working on, the better.
David Wiley.
I don't know how many of you know David Wiley's work, but he's a longtime open education proponent.
He did a little napkin calculation that there are 40,000,000 hours.
And it was a lowball estimate, he said of student work that happened per semester in the United States.
40,000,000 hours of human work and thinking and reflection and writing that could be put to better public use.
And then I did a calculation Ontario.
We have 800,000 students.
Even if they were doing an hour of homework per week, that's 800,000 hours per week times 14 weeks in a semester.
It's a lot of person hours.
That rather than going to a writing assignment that may only be seen by the student and their instructor, goes somewhere else into a project into a report that can be shared publicly.
In terms of open design.
Open learning designer and I am starting to use all of the open tools that I can get my hands on in order to share my work without a learner or educator having to use a password to get to it.
So I use WordPress.
I have my own hosted WordPress site.

I've installed a plugin called Learn Press which makes it look a little bit like a learning management system, which for educators who are my target audience for these modules that I've built is a little bit more familiar.
I don't take it too hard on them.
H5P how many of you know H5P?

H5P is your new favorite open source tool that you ever heard of our friends in Norway have developed a trophy and what it is h5p.org is a set of open source tools that can be used in Word press or learn press or press books.
If you're writing a textbook and press books.
For assessments, you can build multiple choice questions, hot spots, drag and drop fill in the sentence.

There's also accordion tools, so it's a little bit of a design tool if you have a complex diagram and you don't want to show everyone the long explanation, you can use a little accordion tool to open and close it.
So H5P lets me do some of that design work in an open source way.
I also use Google Docs so when I create a course in WordPress or Moodle, if I create it behind a firewall or an email wall.
I will also publish it in Google Docs.
So Google Docs.
I can download an epub, a WordPress file, a PDF.
I can download it in a few ways.
They're useful to me, but what's really important for me is that it's editable.
Most of my work is CC by if I don't care what happens to it.
If if I feel like a publisher might take it and then close it and charge people to use it, I'll also use non commercial.
But for the most part my work is CC by.
But the no sign in no password downloadable, editable, openly licensed formats are really important to me, and although I put inclusive design last on this list, it's first in my design thinking.
Which is multiple pathways, multiple choices ensuring everything is captioned, described, all text, all those things for open design.
So I want to show you a little bit.
The five modules that I have developed and again the target audience for these modules.
If I can get it to come up.
I think I have to drag it somewhere another.
Well, there we go.
Which means I have to drive it from here.
So I have again, this is my experimental education website.
There's all kinds of stuff that I'm doing on here that they're fun and interesting to me.
Oh no, that's.
Sorry bout that.
Do you know also?
Hypothesis educators love hypothesis, so hypothesis is annotation plugin that works with WordPress, which means that students can actually while they're reading an article annotated.
And you can have a group of students, a private group of students annotating something you've asked them to read, and it's a way of demonstrating they've actually read it.
So Group A has to read this week's chapter and they have to annotate it using this software.
It's really fantastic, so it's another thing I recommend is hypothesis.
But what I can't find on this is my.
Menu.
Oh, I know why it's responsive.
Maybe that's it.
Right, so if you go to this website and you choose open courses and again this is neatly using a plugin called Learn Press.
I have a couple of courses here, but the one I want to talk about with you today is the one on SDGS.
And if that's the description here in the description of the courses, again, this link to the Google Docs, which I think is really critical for people, I want people to use this, download it.
It's easy by go ahead and adapt it do anything you want with it.
But so I have got five modules built in here.
I'm going to go to Module 3 'cause I think this is one I have at 5:00 PM.
It does not look as great in responsive design as I'd hoped.
Yeah alright, let's get down some not large text.
So for each MoD, each of the modules and I built five.
I have intended outcomes.
This is about.
I hope you'll be able to take away from the learning.
And then content content.
I've got videos so YouTube videos.
Yeah, I'm not sure why it's looking like this.
I got a little better.
Yeah, that's better.
Thank you.
Great, thank you very much.
So on the left hand side modules navigation that looks a little bit like a learning management system and this is WordPress.
Again, no password is required.
Anyone can come in here and start the learning.
So use of images as examples.
Again, remember, I talked about Naomi.
She's my my threaded example of how this is inquiry based learning.
With assignments for the person who's reading it to learn.
And it it talks.
It's a walk through these modules on how she selects the, uh, sustainable development goal that's interesting to her and how she works on her research project as she goes.
And again, this H5P.
So the purpose of this module for the educator to learn was to learn more about Creative Commons licensing so I can put a little quiz here.
At the end, it's formative.
It doesn't go into a learning management system anywhere, it's just for them to recognize whether or not they've learned the topics I want them to learn.
Additional resources an explore more or things that I would always include in a learning module.
And again, these are for educators to learn more about Creative Commons licenses.
Um?
Attribution image credits in this particular module, there were two YouTube videos.
Again, this is inclusive design, right?
There were two YouTube videos that were captioned Auto caption But not very well.
So I have learned recently that in addition to that, if you include the transcript, that means a student doesn't have to watch the video if they don't want to.
They can just read it.
Which is much faster for them.
As it turns out, so inclusive design in these modules and just a series of five in this particular course.
Modules 6 for this project is going to be the examples from different disciplines.
So how do I use the SDGS to write poetry?
How do I use the SDGS to create films?
How do I use SDGS as learners?
In a language course, what matters about the Sustainable Development Goals?
If I'm learning French, so all those kinds of ideas I want to build examples and have some colleagues around the world have helped me build some examples that I have to get into the system.
In order to show the ways that the SDGS become relevant to any postsecondary discipline.
Any example anyone can use the SDGS for their learner driven assessments or assignments?
It can be small scale, it can be large scale and I need to make the examples as part of finishing up for this project.
So that's really the things that I want to show you again.
If you go to the LD for OEP, that's just learning design for open educational practices.
You can see examples of this and other crazy stuff that I'm working on.
Um?

But in particular this project I'm very excited about the examples that I'm developing and look forward to showing them they will be on this website as module 6, hopefully by the end of the month I'll have about 10 examples that I've been working on put into the system.
So in terms of lessons learned, Latonya asked me about a few lessons.
So I think the critical part of having these modules available to educators is having as many discipline examples as I can.
When I have conversations with educators, they always want to know, OK, oh, we are great, but what can you show me?
An economics?
Can you show me a nicely curated list of Oers in economics?
Can you show me what's available for chemistry?
Can you show me what's available for biology?
We want to see very specific examples, so it is my design drive to show as many discipline examples of IBL and SDGS as I can.
Um, also time management is a huge issue for designers.
It's always a huge issue for me, even worse, when it's my own design rather than a subject matter expert.

So between January and the six month period of getting the design done, I can't recommend working on a dissertation and working full time doing this as passionate as I am about this, I definitely would like to have spent more time on the examples.
I think the modules need to be high level.
And basic so that they are adaptable.
If you get too specific with open learning design, it becomes less useful to people in other parts of the world.
It's harder to translate, it's not.
It's harder to localize contextualize.
So in my work I intentionally.
Tend to go high level, just the basics so it can be adapted.
You can put in your own local examples your own local videos and translate it hopefully more easily.
I don't know how we're doing on time, Tanya.
We should wrap up OK, very good.
I really if you have any questions, I'm happy to talk with you person to person.
I know we have not that much time and lots of people to present.
I love talking about this.
Please take a look at the designs and provide me with any feedback you can that will make them better.
That's a huge part of my design practices to be a collaborative designer so look forward to your feedback.
Great, thank you.
